name: Laravel
title:
[Laravel](https://laravel.com/docs/8.x/) is an expressive and progressive web application framework for PHP. 
This cheat sheet provides a reference for common commands and features for Laravel 8.

cards.title: Intro
cards.body:
[Laravel](https://laravel.com/docs/8.x/) is an expressive and progressive web application framework for PHP. 
This cheat sheet provides a reference for common commands and features for Laravel 8.

cards.title: Requirements
cards.body:
• PHP version >= 7.3
• BCMath PHP Extension
• Ctype PHP Extension
• Fileinfo PHP Extension
• JSON PHP Extension
• Mbstring PHP Extension
• OpenSSL PHP Extension
• PDO PHP Extension
• Tokenizer PHP Extension
• XML PHP Extension

Ensure your web server directs all requests to your application's `public/index.php` file, See:
[Deployment](#deployment)

cards.title: Windows
cards.body:
• #### Install [Docker Desktop](https://www.docker.com/products/docker-desktop)
• #### Install & enable [WSL2](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wsl/install)
• #### Ensure that Docker Desktop is [configured to use WSL2](https://docs.docker.com/desktop/windows/wsl/)
• #### In WSL2 terminal:

cards.code:
$ curl -s https://laravel.build/example-app | bash
      $ cd example-app
      $ ./vendor/bin/sail up

cards.body: Access application via `http://localhost`

cards.title: Mac
cards.body:
• #### Install [Docker Desktop](https://www.docker.com/products/docker-desktop)
• #### In terminal:

cards.code:
$ curl -s https://laravel.build/example-app | bash
      $ cd example-app
      $ ./vendor/bin/sail up

cards.body: Access application via `http://localhost`

cards.title: Linux
cards.code:
$ curl -s https://laravel.build/example-app | bash
$ cd example-app
$ ./vendor/bin/sail up

cards.body: Installation via [Composer](https://getcomposer.org)

cards.code:
$ composer create-project laravel/laravel example-app
$ cd example-app
$ php artisan serve

cards.body: Access application via `http://localhost`

cards.title: CSRF%20Protection
cards.body: Laravel%20automatically%20generates%20a%20CSRF%20%22token%22%20for%20each%20active%20user%20session.%0AThis%20token%20is%20used%20to%20verify%20that%20the%20authenticated%20user%20is%20the%20person%20actually%20making%20the%20requests.
Get current session's token:

`POST`, `PUT`, `PATCH`, or `DELETE` forms should include a hidden CSRF `_token` field in the form to validate the
request.
See [Forms](#forms-cols-3)

cards.title: Intro
cards.body: • [Laravel Docs - Blade Templates](https://laravel.com/docs/8.x/blade)
Blade is the templating engine included in Laravel that also allows you to use plain PHP.

cards.title: Intro
cards.body: • [Laravel Docs - Forms](https://laravel.com/docs/8.x/blade#forms)

cards.title: CSRF Field
cards.body: Include a hidden CSRF token field to validate the request
See: [CSRF Protection](#csrf-protection)

cards.title: Method Field
cards.body:
Since HTML forms can't make `PUT`, `PATCH`, or `DELETE` requests, you will need to add a hidden `_method` field to spoof
these HTTP verbs:
See: [Validation](#validation-cols-3)

cards.title: Repopulating Forms
cards.body:
When redirecting due to a validation error, request input is flashed to the session.
Retrieve the input from the previous request with the `old` method
Or the `old()` helper

cards.title: Intro
cards.body: • [Laravel Docs - Validation](https://laravel.com/docs/8.x/validation)

If validation fails, a redirect response to the previous URL will be generated.
If the incoming request is an XHR request, a JSON response with the validation error messages will be returned.

cards.title: Logic
Rules
cards.body: Can also be passed as an array

cards.title: after:date
cards.body: Field must be a value after a given date.
Instead of a date string, you may specify another field to compare against the date
See [before:date](#beforedate)

cards.title: after_or_equal:date
cards.body:
Field must be a value after or equal to the given date.
See [after:date](#afterdate)

cards.title: before:date
cards.body:
Field must be a value preceding the given date.
The name of another field may be supplied as the value of `date`.
See [after:date](#afterdate)

cards.title: alpha_num
cards.body: Field must be entirely alpha-numeric characters

cards.title: confirmed
cards.body:
Field must have a matching field of `{field}_confirmation`.
For example, if the field is password, a matching `password_confirmation` field must be present

cards.title: current_password
cards.body: Field must match the authenticated user's password.

cards.title: date
cards.body: Field must be a valid, non-relative date according to the `strtotime` PHP function.

cards.title: email
cards.body: Field must be formatted as an email address.

cards.title: file
cards.body:
Field must be a successfully uploaded file.
See: [Uploaded Files](#uploaded-files)

cards.title: max:value
cards.body:
Field must be less than or equal to a maximum value.
Strings, numerics, arrays, and files are evaluated like the [size](#sizevalue) rule.

cards.title: min:value
cards.body:
Field must have a minimum value.
Strings, numerics, arrays, and files are evaluated like the [size](#sizevalue) rule.

cards.title: mimetypes:text/plain,...
cards.body: File must match one of the given MIME types:

File's contents will be read and the framework will attempt to guess the MIME type, regardless of the client's provided
MIME type.

cards.title: mimes:foo,bar,...
cards.body: Field must have a MIME type corresponding to one of the listed extensions.

File's contents will be read and the framework will attempt to guess the MIME type, regardless of the client's provided
MIME type.
[Full listing of MIME types & extensions](https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/httpd/httpd/trunk/docs/conf/mime.types)

cards.title: nullable
cards.body: Field may be null.

cards.title: numeric
cards.body: Field must be numeric.

cards.title: password
cards.body: Field must match the authenticated user's password.

cards.title: prohibited
cards.body: Field must be empty or not present.

cards.title: prohibited_if:anotherfield,value,...
cards.body: Field must be empty or not present if the _anotherfield_ field is equal to any value.

cards.title: prohibited_unless:anotherfield,value,...
cards.body: Field must be empty or not present unless the _anotherfield_ field is equal to any value.

cards.title: required
cards.body: Field%20must%20be%20present%20in%20the%20input%20data%20and%20not%20empty.%0AA%20field%20is%20considered%20%22empty%22%20if%20one%20of%20the%20following%20conditions%20are%20true%3A

• The value is `null`.
• The value is an empty string.
• The value is an empty array or empty `Countable` object.
• The value is an uploaded file with no path.

cards.title: required_with:foo,bar,...
cards.body: Field must be present and not empty, only if any of the other specified fields are present and not empty

cards.title: size:value
cards.body: Field must have a size matching the given value.

• For strings: number of characters
• For numeric data: integer value (must also have the `numeric` or `integer` rule).
• For arrays: count of the array
• For files: file size in kilobytes

cards.title: unique:table,column
cards.body: Field must not exist within the given database table

cards.title: url
cards.body: Field must be a valid URL
[See all available rules](https://laravel.com/docs/8.x/validation#available-validation-rules)

cards.title: Validate Passwords
cards.body: Ensure passwords have an adequate level of complexity
`Password` rule object allows you to easily customize the password complexity requirements
Ensure a password has not been compromised in a public password data breach leak

> _Uses the [k-Anonymity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-anonymity) model via the
> [haveibeenpwned.com](https://haveibeenpwned.com) service without sacrificing the user's privacy or security_
Methods can be chained
See: [Validation Errors](#validation-errors)

cards.title: Optional%20Fields
cards.body: You%20will%20often%20need%20to%20mark%20your%20%22optional%22%20request%20fields%20as%20%60nullable%60%20if%20you%20do%20not%20want%20the%20validator%20to%20consider%0A%60null%60%20values%20as%20invalid

cards.title: Validated Input
cards.body: Retrieve the request data that underwent validation
Or with `safe()`, which returns an instance of `Illuminate\Support\ValidatedInput`

cards.title: Intro
cards.body: • [Laravel Docs - Session](https://laravel.com/docs/8.x/session)

Laravel ships with a variety of session backends that are accessed through a unified API. Memcached, Redis, and database
support is included.

cards.title: Configuration
cards.body:
Session configuration is in `config/session.php`.
By default, Laravel is configured to use the file session driver

cards.title: Check Isset / Exists
cards.body: Returns `true` if the item is present and is not `null`:
Returns `true` if present, even if it's `null`:
Returns `true` if the item is `null` or is not present:

cards.body: Pass a default value as the second argument to use if the key does not exist

cards.body: See: [Session Helper]()

cards.title: Retrieve and Delete
cards.body: Retrieve and delete an item from the session

cards.title: Store Data
cards.body: Via a request instance
Via%20the%20global%20%22session%22%20helper
Push a new value onto a session value that is an array

cards.title: Configuration
cards.body:
Configuration options for logging behavior is in `config/logging.php`.
By default, Laravel will use the stack channel when logging messages, which aggregates multiple log channels into a
single channel.

cards.title: Levels
cards.body: All the log levels defined in the [RFC 5424 specification](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5424) are available:

• emergency
• alert
• critical
• error
• warning
• notice
• info
• debug

cards.title: Log Facade
Contextual Info
cards.code:
use Illuminate\Support\Facades\Log;

Log::info('User failed to login.', ['id' => $user->id]);

cards.title: Intro
cards.body: • [Laravel Docs - Deployment](https://laravel.com/docs/8.x/deployment)
Ensure your web server directs all requests to your application's `public/index.php` file

cards.title: Configuration Loading
cards.body:
Be sure that you are only calling the `env` function from within your configuration files.
Once the configuration has been cached, the `.env` file will not be loaded and all calls to the `env` function for
`.env` variables will return `null`

cards.title: Debug Mode
cards.body:
The debug option in your `config/app.php` determines how much information about an error is actually displayed to the
user.
By default, this option is set to the value of the `APP_DEBUG` environment variable in your `.env` file. In your
production environment, this value should always be `false`.
If the `APP_DEBUG` variable is set to `true` in production, you risk exposing sensitive configuration values to end
users.
